title: Falcon 180B emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of energy consumption data of Falcon 180B, this information is extrapolated from available data on Falcon 7B. The number of parameters in Falcon 7B is 7 billion, whereas Falcon 180B has a much larger parameter count of 180 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to Falcon 180B requires 25x more energy.

Further note that in the Hugging Face experiment, the prompt size is 256 tokens, and the output size is 256 tokens, too. However, the "Energy" value refers to 1 generated completion token. As there is no reason to believe that prompt tokens consume no energy, we apply factor 0.5x here, but use both prompt and completion tokens for our calculation.

title: Falcon 7B
description: The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Falcon model with 7B parameters handles 422,919 completion tokens/kWh. Per token, that's 1/422919 = 2.4e-6 kWh.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Ludvigsen)
description:
Kasper Groes Albin Ludvigsen approximated the carbon footprint of ChatGPT. The calculation and the underlying assumptions he made are further illustrated in this carbon footprint scenario.

In January 2023, ChatGPT had about 100M unique users who made 590M queries to GPT-3. The estimated emissions associated with these requests have been modeled below. To explore further, adjust the quantity in the input field or click on the link.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, Ludvigsen relates to the large language model BLOOM instead. Both models are roughly the same size â€” 175b vs 176b parameters for GPT-3 and BLOOM respectively.

The experiment handled 230,768 queries in total, so the fraction for one request is 1/230768 = 4.3334e-6

title: BLOOM model experiment
description:
Alexandra Sasha Luccioni et al. published a study on the the carbon footprint of the BLOOM model. With its 176 billion parameters, BLOOM is a large language model (LLM) that is able to generate text in 46 natural languages and 13 programming languages. The researchers ran their experiment on 16 Nvidia A100 GPUs during 18 days. The model handled 230,768 queries in the course of the experiment. In total, the system consumed 914 kWh of electriciy for CPU, RAM and GPU usage.

For the emissions, we used a grid emissions factor for Western USA (WECC) from EPA.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Pointon)
description:
Chris Pointon approximated the carbon footprint of ChatGPT. The calculation and the underlying assumptions he made are further illustrated in this carbon footprint scenario.

In January 2023, ChatGPT had about 100M unique users who made 590M queries to GPT-3. The estimated emissions associated with these requests have been modeled below. To explore further, adjust the quantity in the input field or click on the link.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-3
description: Chris Pointon assumes that each query to ChatGPT generates in average 30 words.

title: Carbon emission of 1 output word generated by GPT-3
description:
Tom Goldstein, Professor at U of Maryland, extrapolates that if GPT-3 were to run on a single Nvidia A100 GPU, it would take 350 ms to output one word.

The fraction of such an operation of one hour is 350/3600000 = 9.7222e-5

title: Hourly emission by GPU running at full load
description:
The author assumes that ChatGPT is hosted in an Azure datacenter in California, running on Nvidia Tesla A100 GPUs.

Thus, he takes as starting point the energy consumption of this processor under full load as provided by Cloud Carbon Footprint (407 Watts per hour). For the emissions, he uses a grid emissions factor for Western USA (WECC) from EPA.

title: GPT-3 emission per token (Pointon)
description:
Tom Goldstein, Professor at U of Maryland, extrapolates that if GPT-3 were to run on a single Nvidia A100 GPU, it would take 350 ms to output one word.

The fraction of such an operation of one hour is 350/3600000 = 9.7222e-5

As this calculation ignores the impact of the prompt on the energy consumption, we assume an equal number of prompt tokens and apply factor 0.5x to obtain a per-token value.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Ruf & Mortas)
description: In this scenario, we approximate the carbon footprint of ChatGPT based on the Llama 2 model and energy consumption data from Hugging Face.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-3
description: We assume that each query to ChatGPT generates in average 1,319 tokens.

title: GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 2. The number of parameters in Llama 2 is 68.98 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 2.5x more energy.

title: Llama 2
description: The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Llama 2 model with 70B parameters handles 163,934 completion tokens/kWh. Per token, that's 1/163934 = 6.1e-6 kWh.

title: Llama 3
description: The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Llama 3 model with 8B parameters handles 201,527 completion tokens/kWh. Per token, that's 1/201527 = 5.1e-6 kWh.

title: GPT-3 emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 2. The number of parameters in Llama 2 is 68.98 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 2.5x more energy.

Further note that in the Hugging Face experiment, the prompt size is 256 tokens, and the output size is 256 tokens, too. However, the "Energy" value refers to 1 generated completion token. As there is no reason to believe that prompt tokens consume no energy, we apply factor 0.5x here, but use both prompt and completion tokens for our calculation.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Selvan)
description:
Raghavendra Selvan from University of Copenhagen approximated the carbon footprint of ChatGPT. The calculation and the underlying assumptions he made are further illustrated in this carbon footprint scenario.

In January 2023, ChatGPT had about 100M unique users who made 590M queries to GPT-3. The estimated emissions associated with these requests have been modeled below. To explore further, adjust the quantity in the input field or click on the link.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Selvan)
description:
Raghavendra Selvan from University of Copenhagen approximated the carbon footprint of ChatGPT. The calculation and the underlying assumptions he made are further illustrated in this carbon footprint scenario.

In January 2023, ChatGPT had about 100M unique users who made 590M queries to GPT-3. The estimated emissions associated with these requests have been modeled below. To explore further, adjust the quantity in the input field or click on the link.

title: GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from a freely available open source language model (GPT-J). Scaling to GPT-3, the following factors are taken into account:

1. The number of parameters in GPT-J is 6 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion. By a conservative estimate, the larger model could require 10x additional GPUs.

2. To fit the test environment, the GPT-J model is initialized in half-precision. The overhead of running a full precision model compared to half precision is about 1.5x more.

Therefore, it is assumed that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 15x more energy compared to submitting a query to GPT-J.

title: GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from a freely available open source language model (GPT-J). Scaling to GPT-3, the following factors are taken into account:

1. The number of parameters in GPT-J is 6 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion. By a conservative estimate, the larger model could require 10x additional GPUs.

2. To fit the test environment, the GPT-J model is initialized in half-precision. The overhead of running a full precision model compared to half precision is about 1.5x more.

Therefore, it is assumed that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 15x more energy compared to submitting a query to GPT-J.

title: GPT-J
description:
To estimate the carbon footprint of GPT-J, a freely available language model with 6 billion parameters, Raghavendra Selvan ran experiments on a local workstation. The model was initialized in half-precision (16 bit float instead of 32 bit float) to fit into GPU memory. The average length of text generated by the model was 230 words. The energy consumption got measured with CarbonTracker, a tool developed by researchers from University of Copenhagen.

As a result, one request to GPT-J consumed in average 0.01292 kWh.

title: GPT-J
description:
To estimate the carbon footprint of GPT-J, a freely available language model with 6 billion parameters, Raghavendra Selvan ran experiments on a local workstation. The model was initialized in half-precision (16 bit float instead of 32 bit float) to fit into GPU memory. The average length of text generated by the model was 230 words. The energy consumption got measured with CarbonTracker, a tool developed by researchers from University of Copenhagen.

As a result, one request to GPT-J consumed in average 0.01292 kWh.

title: GPT-3 emission per token (Selvan)
description:
The outputs in this experiment generate in average 230 words. We apply factor 1/230 to get the emissions per completion token.

As this calculation ignores the impact of the prompt on the energy consumption, we assume an equal number of prompt tokens and apply factor 0.5x to obtain a per-token value.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-4 estimated using Llama 3
description: We assume that each query to ChatGPT generates in average 1,319 tokens.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-4 estimated using Llama 2
description: We assume that each query to ChatGPT generates in average 1,319 tokens.

title: GPT-4 emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-4, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 3. The number of parameters in this version of Llama 3 is 8 billion, whereas GPT-4 might have a much larger parameter count of 1.76 trillion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-4 requires 220x more energy.

title: GPT-4 estimated using Llama 2
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-4, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 2. The number of parameters in this version of Llama 2 is 68.98 billion, whereas GPT-4 might have a much larger parameter count of 1.76 trillion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-4 requires 25.5x more energy.

title: Paris to Dublin by train and ferry
description: Paris â€“ London â€“ Holyhead â€“ Dublin

title: GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from a freely available open source language model (GPT-J). Scaling to GPT-3, the following factors are taken into account:

1. The number of parameters in GPT-J is 6 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion. By a conservative estimate, the larger model could require 10x additional GPUs.

2. To fit the test environment, the GPT-J model is initialized in half-precision. The overhead of running a full precision model compared to half precision is about 1.5x more.

Therefore, it is assumed that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 15x more energy compared to submitting a query to GPT-J.

title: Warming 1L of water from 18 to 38Â°C
description:
Before being heated, the temperature of the water in a tank is 18Â°C.
Most people take a shower at 38Â°C (a little bit above body temperature).

According to thermodynamic, heating 1L of water from 18 to 38Â°C consume 0.0232 kWh.

Formula: Energy [kWh] = (mass of water [g] x specific heat capacity [J/gÂ°C] x delta T [Â°C]) / conversion coefficient [J/kWh]
Details: (1 000 x 4.18 x (38 - 18)) / 3 600 000 = 0.0232

title: 1 hot shower
description:
The average flow rate of a shower is 15L/minute. The average time for a shower in France is 9 minutes [source].
The volume of water used in a shower is 135 L.

Formula: Volume [L] = flow rate [L/min] x time [minutes]
Details: 15 * 9 = 135

title: GPT-J
description:
To estimate the carbon footprint of GPT-J, a freely available language model with 6 billion parameters, Raghavendra Selvan ran experiments on a local workstation. The model was initialized in half-precision (16 bit float instead of 32 bit float) to fit into GPU memory. The average length of text generated by the model was 230 words. The energy consumption got measured with CarbonTracker, a tool developed by researchers from University of Copenhagen.

As a result, one request to GPT-J consumed in average 0.01292 kWh.

title: Monthly business travel in 2019
description: The AXA Group published a carbon footprint of 90.6kt CO2e for their business travel in 2019. To obtain the average monthly emissions, we use the fraction of 0.08333333333.
